snp2.5:270: “What is the source of lust and hatred?Where are born discontent, delight, and hair-raising terror?Having originated from what do the mind’s thoughtstoss one around as boys toss up a crow?”Most editions of Sn andSN 10.3, as well as their commentaries, read:kumārakā dhaṅkam iv’ ossajanti. A variantvaṅkamis found in several manuscripts. Anderson and Smith chosevaṅkamfor their edition of Sn, but in his edition ofPj II, Smith replaced it withdhaṅkaṃ, which I adopt. Norman discusses the line atGD211–12.(1)
snp2.5:271: “Lust and hatred have their source here;from this are born discontent, delight, and hair-raising terror.Having originated from this, the mind’s thoughtstoss one around as boys toss up a crow. (2) [49]
snp2.5:272: Benumbers both the preceding verse and this one 274.However,Pj II(Be) numbers the two verses 274 and 275, and thus at this point the numbering ofPj II(Be) outstrips that of Sn (Be) by one.“Born from affection, arisen from oneself,like the trunk-born shoots of the banyan tree,manifold, attached to sensual pleasures,like a māluvācreeper stretched across the woods. (3)
snp2.5:273: “Those who understand their source,they dispel it — listen, O yakkha! —they cross this flood so hard to cross,uncrossed before, for no renewed existence.” (4)
